abstract.p: Andrei Lahnstein letter says that some regions of Russia are more democratic than federal government in Moscow (S)

block.p: Your May 22 news article implies that most of Russia's regional governors are authoritarian, when in fact some regions are more democratic than the federal government in Moscow.
During the last gubernatorial elections, several regional governors lost their seats in multi-candidate contests. In contrast, no Russian leader has ever been defeated by ballot.
Your May 22 news article implies that most of Russia's regional governors are authoritarian, when in fact some regions are more democratic than the federal government in Moscow.
During the last gubernatorial elections, several regional governors lost their seats in multi-candidate contests. In contrast, no Russian leader has ever been defeated by ballot.
And President Vladimir V. Putin's war in Chechnya can hardly be considered an exercise in democracy. No Russian governor is currently waging a war against his own population.
In many regions, local legislatures and the judiciary are independent of the governor while the equivalent federal branches are dominated by the president.
It would be a mistake to assume that Mr. Putin's move to tighten his rule over the regions would be a step toward a more democratic Russia.
